item.title: By: Helmut
item.dc:creator: Helmut
item.description: <p>I need to pass a filename on to a viewer page: <br /><a href="view.html?/x/pix1.jpg">pix1</a><br /><br />and then read the value into a variable, for example ppp, that I can use to display that picture, for example<br /><img src="<!--#echo var="ppp" -->"><br /><br />What code do I need to read the value and stuff it into ppp ?<br />Thanks<br />Helmut</p>
item.content:encoded:
I need to pass a filename on to a viewer page:
<a href=”view.html?/x/pix1.jpg”>pix1</a>

and then read the value into a variable, for example ppp, that I can use to display that picture, for example
<img src=”<!–#echo var=”ppp” –>”>

What code do I need to read the value and stuff it into ppp ?
Thanks
Helmut

item.title: By: Leonard
item.dc:creator: Leonard
item.description: <p><!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"><br /><br /><html><br /><head><br /><title>Untitled</title><br /></head><br /><body><br /><script language="javascript"><br />function getURLParam(strParamName){<br /> var strReturn = "";<br /> var strHref = window.location.href;<br /> if ( strHref.indexOf("?") > -1 ){<br /> var strQueryString = strHref.substr(strHref.indexOf("?")).toLowerCase();<br /> var aQueryString = strQueryString.split("&");<br /> for ( var iParam = 0; iParam < aQueryString.length; iParam++ ){<br /> if (<br />aQueryString[iParam].indexOf(strParamName.toLowerCase() + "=") > -1 ){<br /> var aParam = aQueryString[iParam].split("=");<br /> strReturn = aParam[1];<br /> break;<br /> }<br /> }<br /> }<br /> return unescape(strReturn);<br />} <br /></script><br /></body><br /></html><br /><br /><br />{ <a href="<a rel="nofollow" href="http://localhost/test.php?id=testid"" rel="nofollow ugc">http://localhost/test.php?id=testid"</a> rel="nofollow" target ="blank">Link</a> }<br /><br />...why doesn't this work?</p>
item.content:encoded:
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC “-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN”>

<html>
<head>
<title>Untitled</title>
</head>
<body>
<script language=”javascript”>
function getURLParam(strParamName){
var strReturn = “”;
var strHref = window.location.href;
if ( strHref.indexOf(“?”) > -1 ){
var strQueryString = strHref.substr(strHref.indexOf(“?”)).toLowerCase();
var aQueryString = strQueryString.split(“&”);
for ( var iParam = 0; iParam < aQueryString.length; iParam++ ){
if (
aQueryString[iParam].indexOf(strParamName.toLowerCase() + “=”) > -1 ){
var aParam = aQueryString[iParam].split(“=”);
strReturn = aParam[1];
break;
}
}
}
return unescape(strReturn);
}
</script>
</body>
</html>

{ http://localhost/test.php?id=testid“ rel=”nofollow” target =”blank”>Link }

…why doesn’t this work?

item.title: By: Rik Arends
item.dc:creator: Rik Arends
item.description: <p>Note to moderator: Sorry, made a codetypo in the previous post please remove it and this line<br/><br /><br/><br />Alright, i added support for [] style PHP arrays and objects. <br/><br />It autodetects if it needs to create an object or an array, depending on the type of the index. String creates an object, number creates an array. <br/><br />Due to a special case in the code [-1] is treated as []. Besides, negative array indices are evil. <br/><br />examples: <br/><br /><br/><br />http : //ur/page?val[]=1&val[]=2&val[]=3; <br/><br />Will be accessible as an array: <br/><br />_GET.val[0] to _GET.val[2] <br/><br /><br/><br />http : //ur/page?val[v1]=1&val.v2=2; <br/><br />Will be accessible as an object: <br/><br />_GET.val.v1 and _GET.val.v2 <br/><br /><br/><br />The code supports n-levels. <br/><br />http : //ur/page?val[v1][0]=1; <br/><br />Which will be stored as an array in <br/><br />_GET.val.v1[0] <br/><br /><br/><br />You can put quotes around names to force 'object' as type <br/><br />http : //ur/page?val[v1]['1']=1; <br/><br />Which will be stored properly stripped as an object: <br/><br />_GET.val.v1['1'] <br/><br /><br/><br />The code is below, formatting is a bit off on this post, make it nicer if that makes you feel better :) <br/><br /><br/><br /><br/><br />var _GET = {};<br/><br />for(var i,a,m,n,o,v,p=location.href.split(/[?&]/),l=p.length,k=1;k<l;k++)<br/><br /> if( (m=p[k].match(/(.*?)(\..*?|\[.*?\])?=([^#]*)/))&&m.length==4){<br/><br /> n=decodeURI(m[1]).toLowerCase(),o=_GET,v=decodeURI(m[3]);<br/><br /> if(m[2])for(a=decodeURI(m[2]).replace(/\[\s*\]/g,"[-1]").split(/[\.\[\]]/),i=0;i<a.length;i++)<br/><br /> o=o[n]?o[n]:o[n]=(parseInt(a<i>)==a<i>)?[]:{}, n=a<i>.replace(/^["\'](.*)["\']$/,"$1");<br/><br /> n!='-1'?o[n]=v:o[o.length]=v;<br/><br />}</p>
item.content:encoded:
Note to moderator: Sorry, made a codetypo in the previous post please remove it and this line

Alright, i added support for [] style PHP arrays and objects.

It autodetects if it needs to create an object or an array, depending on the type of the index. String creates an object, number creates an array.

Due to a special case in the code [-1] is treated as []. Besides, negative array indices are evil.

examples:

http : //ur/page?val[]=1&val[]=2&val[]=3;

Will be accessible as an array:

_GET.val[0] to _GET.val[2]

http : //ur/page?val[v1]=1&val.v2=2;

Will be accessible as an object:

_GET.val.v1 and _GET.val.v2

The code supports n-levels.

http : //ur/page?val[v1][0]=1;

Which will be stored as an array in

_GET.val.v1[0]

You can put quotes around names to force ‘object’ as type

http : //ur/page?val[v1][‘1’]=1;

Which will be stored properly stripped as an object:

_GET.val.v1[‘1’]

The code is below, formatting is a bit off on this post, make it nicer if that makes you feel better ðŸ™‚

var _GET = {};

for(var i,a,m,n,o,v,p=location.href.split(/[?&]/),l=p.length,k=1;k<l;k++)

if( (m=p[k].match(/(.*?)(\..*?|\[.*?\])?=([^#]*)/))&&m.length==4){

n=decodeURI(m[1]).toLowerCase(),o=_GET,v=decodeURI(m[3]);

if(m[2])for(a=decodeURI(m[2]).replace(/\[\s*\]/g,”[-1]”).split(/[\.\[\]]/),i=0;i<a.length;i++)

o=o[n]?o[n]:o[n]=(parseInt(a)==a)?[]:{}, n=a.replace(/^[“\’](.*)[“\’]$/,”$1”);

n!=’-1′?o[n]=v:o[o.length]=v;

}
